Operation 'digitalassetlinks.assetlinks.bulkCheck' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Missing summary entirely. Description lacks clarity about return format and response structure. Added explicit mention of BulkCheckResponse format, ordering guarantee, and error handling to improve AI agent understanding of what to expect from this operation.

data.current_description: Send a bundle of statement checks in a single RPC to minimize latency and service load. Statements need not be all for the same source and/or target. We recommend using this method when you need to check more than one statement in a short period of time.
data.summary_suggestion: Check multiple asset link relationships in a single request
data.description_suggestion: Verifies multiple digital asset link relationships in a single RPC call to minimize latency and service load. Accepts a batch of statement checks where statements can target different source and target assets. Returns a list of CheckResponse objects in the same order as the requests, with individual results and any errors for each statement. Recommended when checking more than one relationship within a short time period.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description lacks clarity about return format and response structure. Added explicit mention of BulkCheckResponse format, ordering guarantee, and error handling to improve AI agent understanding of what to expect from this operation.

message: Operation 'digitalassetlinks.assetlinks.check' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose and mixes security details with operational details. Reorganized to lead with core functionality, then explain use cases and security implications. Added explicit mention of CheckResponse return type for better AI agent understanding of outputs.

data.current_description: Determines whether the specified (directional) relationship exists between the specified source and target assets. The relation describes the intent of the link between the two assets as claimed by the source asset. An example for such relationships is the delegation of privileges or permissions. This command is most often used by infrastructure systems to check preconditions for an action. For example, a client may want to know if it is OK to send a web URL to a particular mobile app instead. The client can check for the relevant asset link from the website to the mobile app to decide if the operation should be allowed. A note about security: if you specify a secure asset as the source, such as an HTTPS website or an Android app, the API will ensure that any statements used to generate the response have been made in a secure way by the owner of that asset. Conversely, if the source asset is an insecure HTTP website (that is, the URL starts with `http://` instead of `https://`), the API cannot verify its statements securely, and it is not possible to ensure that the website's statements have not been altered by a third party. For more information, see the [Digital Asset Links technical design specification](https://github.com/google/digitalassetlinks/blob/master/well-known/details.md).
data.summary_suggestion: Verify a directional asset link relationship exists
data.description_suggestion: Verifies whether a specified directional relationship exists between a source asset and target asset. The relationship represents the intent of the link as claimed by the source asset (e.g., delegation of privileges). Returns a CheckResponse indicating whether the relationship exists and any relevant statements. Security note: For secure sources (HTTPS websites, Android apps), the API verifies statements were made securely by the asset owner. For insecure HTTP sources, statement verification cannot be guaranteed. Commonly used by infrastructure systems to check preconditions before allowing operations like redirecting to related apps or websites.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose and mixes security details with operational details. Reorganized to lead with core functionality, then explain use cases and security implications. Added explicit mention of CheckResponse return type for better AI agent understanding of outputs.

message: Operation 'digitalassetlinks.statements.list' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose with redundant security information. Reorganized to clearly state what the operation retrieves, what it returns (ListResponse), and when to use it. Condensed security guarantees and added explicit mention of return type for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description: Retrieves a list of all statements from a given source that match the specified target and statement string. The API guarantees that all statements with secure source assets, such as HTTPS websites or Android apps, have been made in a secure way by the owner of those assets, as described in the [Digital Asset Links technical design specification](https://github.com/google/digitalassetlinks/blob/master/well-known/details.md). Specifically, you should consider that for insecure websites (that is, where the URL starts with `http://` instead of `https://`), this guarantee cannot be made. The `List` command is most useful in cases where the API client wants to know all the ways in which two assets are related, or enumerate all the relationships from a particular source asset. Example: a feature that helps users navigate to related items. When a mobile app is running on a device, the feature would make it easy to navigate to the corresponding web site or Google+ profile.
data.summary_suggestion: List all asset link statements matching source and target
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves all statements from a specified source asset that match the given target asset and statement relationship type. Returns a ListResponse containing matching Statement objects. The API guarantees secure verification for statements with secure sources (HTTPS websites, Android apps); insecure HTTP sources cannot be verified. Useful for discovering all relationships between two assets or enumerating all relationships from a particular source asset, such as enabling navigation features between related web and mobile properties.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose with redundant security information. Reorganized to clearly state what the operation retrieves, what it returns (ListResponse), and when to use it. Condensed security guarantees and added explicit mention of return type for better AI agent interpretability.
